rate doesn't indicate a high chance of this happening.

Then add in ideology etc and this probability comes down even further
Iran needs much more time and cultural change in order to restrict use of death penalty.

Iran's politics move too slowly for this.  The opposition to the legislation is religious-based.  The first hurdle is getting it through the Majles.  On paper, the moderate-reformist coalition is in charge.  In truth, its center is moderate conservative.  Even if the Majles approves, the GC will likely hold it up on technicalities.  It will just be another "razieh": a Shi'ite passion play.  The real decisionmaker is the Supreme Leader Khamanei who has taken very conservative stances.

Gut instinct.  The legislation will pass, but after 18 October 2016.  Likely within ten years, but after international events further empower females around the world which infuses more compassionate discussions in relation to children.

There seems to be little genuine appetite for this amongst the Iranian leadership. The use of the death penalty, and the terror that it spreads, has been a cornerstone of Iranian government control since the revolution. Even the reformist Rouhani has done little to agitate in favour of its limitation. Indeed, there is some reason to think that, since his appointment in 2013, the frequency of executions in Iran has actually increased (with 2015 being a particularly bloody year). Moreover, getting the Majles to consider (very publically) an apparently liberalising policy which then does not get past the Guardian Council is a common tactic in Iran - it is an effective, low-risk ploy used by the regime as propaganda both internally and externally to demonstrate their apparent 'openness' to new ideas.

Unlikely in this time span.  The hardliners are experiencing a boom in blowback to the deal.  Additionally, the RG's control of the economy and means of production will not allow Liberals to reap any benefits this quickly.  It'll happen, but much more slowly.
Even if they agree to soften their stance in their war on drugs (to secure more western aid), it will probably informal, not legislative.
The Guardian Council wouldn't pass anything that goes against the religion

This is a broadly worded question.  Even if the legislation mentioned in the question doesn't pass, it is possible that some unrelated legislation restricting the death penalty in marginal cases could pass.  The confidence of other forecasters doesn't seem warranted.

The religious laws are very key components of Iranian system. The Guardian Council is mostly nominated from hardliners because there is a veto rights to disband moderate candidates. Memebers of Guardian Council have to be dedicated to islamic values so it leaves no room for reformists. I am keen to belive that Iran will still keep Islam laws so important that no big changes will happen to 18. 2016. Also most death penalties are related to drugs and i dont believe there will be any change that either.  The amount of death penalties has grown big since 2010. That will also be negative factor if we consider the change in this issue.
Such a step will probably be a little too radical for them

No - too much power from the radicals still

The death penalty in Iran is rooted deeply in both Iranian religion and culture. In religious terms the argument for the death penalty is pretty clear: the Koran prescribes it and Iran is essentially a theocracy in which religious clerics have control over the levers of power.
Culturally, there isn't a great deal of mainstream opposition to the death penalty and the population (in general) and politicians see it as both a punishment and an integral mechanism for deterring future criminal activity.

Unlikely within the next four months. However, Iran currently has 17 capital drug-related offenses and there is a slight possibility that international pressure could see one or two of these downgraded to imprisonment as a gesture of appeasement. Other than that, no chance.

There will be a ceasing of death penalty for drug offenses , which has been the bulk of the death penalties in Iran.

The Guardian Council has twelve members, six theologians appointed directly by the Supreme Leader, and another six jurists nominated by the judiciary.  It has a very conservative mindset, as was seen in the recent Majles elections when it disqualified almost all of the candidates considered to  be moderate or reformist. It can be taken for granted that anyone nominated by the current Supreme Leader will be very conservative. Similarly, the judiciary is a very conservative institution too and so will its nominees be.
How many people are executed every year in Iran?

Offhand, not much reason to believe that such legislation would get the okey-dokey from the cognizant poobahs.  It is possible to suspect that they think they've given away too much already.  This may happen after a while, but not probable before this date.

In recent open sources it was indicated that in Iran, emerging from isolation after the lifting of nuclear-related sanctions, at least 977 people were executed in 2015, up 31% from the 2014 figure of at least 743. The vast majority were for drug-related offences. Iran is one of the last executioners of child offenders, in violation of international law. Last year it executed at least four people who were under 18 at the time of their crime.  In states that have a high application of the death penalty, primarily for drug offenses in Islamic countries include:  China, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam, Indonesia.  However, China (which currently has the highest death penalty rate), Singapore and Vietnam also implement policies for reasons of drug offenses of various kinds.
